qas.question: Is there a universal definition of astham?

answers.text: there is not one universal agreed upon definition

qas.question: What main components play a role in asthma?

answers.text: many cells and cellular elements play a role

qas.question: What is the inflamation a result of?
What does hyper-responsiveness of the airways cause?

answers.text: episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness and coughing

qas.question: What are two ways to reverse an asthma attack?

plausible_answers.text: a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways in which many cells and cellular elements play a role
there is not one universal agreed upon definition

qas.question: Is there a universally agreed upon definition of cellular obstruction?
How do you stop the symptoms of cellular obstruction?

plausible_answers.text: wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness and coughing

qas.question: What does hyper-responsiveness at the cellular level cause?

context: While asthma is a well recognized condition, <a0_0><b6_0>there is not one universal agreed upon definition<b6_0/><a0_0/>. It is defined by the Global Initiative for Asthma as "<b5_0>a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways in which <a1_0>many cells and cellular elements play a role<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The chronic inflammation is associated with <a2_0><b7_0>airway hyper-responsiveness<b7_0/><a2_0/> that leads to recurrent <a3_0>episodes of <b9_0>wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness and coughing<b9_0/><a3_0/> particularly at night or in the early morning. These episodes are usually associated with widespread but variable airflow obstruction within the lung that is often reversible <b8_0>either <a4_0>spontaneously or with treatment<b8_0/><a4_0/>".
